publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in ŠorčuqStadthöhle oder Nāgarāja-Höhleduring T III Š 64, T III Š 90, T III Š 101

seg.seg: ... || This book (is meant) for Porociṃ Monastery ... ? ... without permission ... (not?) to be taken (away from the monastery?) ... This book (belongs) to Porociṃ Monastery. This book (you may not take?) out of Porociṃ Monastery

p.note: – (p)räl: It is suggestive to think of (mā p)räl '[This book] is (not) to be taken [away from the monastery].'

In the last section in this line, the oblique case of caṣ postäk requires another construction than the standard säs postäk mā präl 'this book is not to be taken'. If mar is read correctly, the corresponding subjunctive could simply have to be restored, i.e. 2Sg.Sub.Mid. mar (kāmatār) 'you may not take; don't take!' or 3Sg.Sub.Mid. mar (kāmatär) 'he may not take'.

The position of the following akṣaras ·e präm suggests that they belong to the preceding "colophon" ending with saṃ(k)r(ā)ma(c), but the akṣaras themselves are larger and not well formed, which points to a later addition.
Sanskrit text (lines -) containing glosses and a colophon in TA (and TB?) on verso.
The Sanskrit text has been omitted from the transcription/transliteration.

– – aplā: The meaning of the scribbling in careful faint handwriting is fairly clear: it must be the word for "without permission". However, as far as it can be deciphered, it rather resembles the TB term aplākätte. The TA equivalent is so far unattested, but the first a should in any case have been long, i.e. *āplākät (or perhaps *āplakät). A reading [ā]plā cannot be excluded completely: these akṣaras are covered by much larger akṣaras in careless handwriting, which very clearly read aplā, i.e. TB aplā«kätte». Thus, we expect TA in view of the other scribblings in TA, and the faint first note might be in TA, but the second, larger scribbling seems to be in TB.

This colophon, or rather indication of ownership, is found at the end of the Udānavarga text. In the system of 31, it is manuscript AA, leaf (129). Faint traces of an earlier now undcipherable gloss are covered by sas\, [s]·äk\ and saṃ. For the monastery name Porociṃ, which also occurs in a later addition to A 54, A 54 a2bis, and in , see 112-114, who suggests that it can perhaps be identified with the so-called "Stadthöhle" in Šorčuq.

Under the last section of this line (caṣ postäk...) a smaller and fainter line is found. Under postäk the word [ku]sne 'who' is relatively clear, but the following cannot be deciphered: under por[o]ci[ṃ] 110 reads as above, b4x.
The unskilled akṣaras to the left of mokṣakute ṣāmner appear to make no sense; the akṣaras to the right of it so far allow for no interpretation.

list.item: b4 ... || säs pos(t)äk porociṃ saṃ(k)r(ā)ma(c) ... ·e präm ... – – aplā«kät» ... – (mā p)räl ... – caṣ postäk porociṃ saṅkrāmäṣ pre mar /// b4x kusne – m ·rä mā – b5 sā sā ka kā ka k· ... mokṣakute ṣāmner ... – – – mä pa kyā – – – ... su – nte – ·i –
T III Š 64, T III Š 90, T III Š 101

Sanskrit text (lines a1-b4) containing glosses and a colophon in TA (and TB?) on verso.

The Sanskrit text has been omitted from the transcription/transliteration.

• How to transliterate/-scribe such cases, where colophons/glosses in TA and/or TB are scribbled/added at the end of a text, partially overlapping?
  • Peyrot, forth. is quoted in [[Peyrot 2015b]]: 127 as Peyrot, Michaël (forth.) "The Sanskrit Udānavarga and the Tocharian B Udānastotra: a window on the relationship between religious and popular language on the northern Silk Road". Add bib entry once it's been published (TI).
    • Done. It's [[Peyrot 2016a]], but the pages need to be added. –Martin (Thu, 2018-07-26, 19:24:27 (CEST))
  • I changed the expedition code from "T III So 64, 90, 101" (which was copied from IDP) to "T III Š 64" etc. (which is written on both, the fragments and the frame). I also added the images and the link to IDP. –Martin (Thu, 2018-07-26, 19:29:45 (CEST))
  • The different parts of the text, now irregularly separated by "...", have yet to be marked correctly. –Martin (Tue, 2018-10-09, 14:28:57 (CEST))

b4 ... || This book (is meant) for Porociṃ Monastery ... ? ... without permission ... (not?) to be taken (away from the monastery?) ... This book (belongs) to Porociṃ Monastery. This book (you may not take?) out of Porociṃ Monastery b4x who ... b5 ... śramaṇera Mokṣagupta ...

b4 This colophon, or rather indication of ownership, is found at the end of the Udānavarga text. In the system of [[Bernhard 1965]]: 31, it is manuscript AA, leaf (129). Faint traces of an earlier now undcipherable gloss are covered by sas\, [s]·äk\ and saṃ. For the monastery name Porociṃ, which also occurs in a later addition to A 54, A 54 a2bis, and in [[THT 4023]]: 1, see [[Ogihara 2014]]: 112-114, who suggests that it can perhaps be identified with the so-called "Stadthöhle" in Šorčuq.

The position of the following akṣaras ·e präm suggests that they belong to the preceding "colophon" ending with saṃ(k)r(ā)ma(c), but the akṣaras themselves are larger and not well formed, which points to a later addition.

b4x Under the last section of this line (caṣ postäk...) a smaller and fainter line is found. Under postäk the word [ku]sne 'who' is relatively clear, but the following cannot be deciphered: under por[o]ci[ṃ] [[Peyrot 2015b]]: 110 reads as above, b4x.

b4 ... || _s_a_s\ [pos]·ä_k\ porociṃ saṃ·r·m[a]·^ä ... ·e [_p]_r_a_m\ ... – – [a]plā ... – ·[_r]_a_l\• ... – ca_ṣ\ postä_k\ por[o]ci[ṃ] sa[ṅ]krā_m_a_ṣ\ [p]re m[a_r] /// b4x [ku]sne – [_m]\ ·_r_a mā – b5 sā sā ka kā ka [k]· ... mokṣakute ṣāmn[e]_r ... – – – [_m_a] [p]a k[y]ā – – – ... su – nte – ·i –

b4 – – aplā: The meaning of the scribbling in careful faint handwriting is fairly clear: it must be the word for "without permission". However, as far as it can be deciphered, it rather resembles the TB term aplākätte. The TA equivalent is so far unattested, but the first a should in any case have been long, i.e. *āplākät (or perhaps *āplakät). A reading [ā]plā cannot be excluded completely: these akṣaras are covered by much larger akṣaras in careless handwriting, which very clearly read aplā, i.e. TB aplā«kätte». Thus, we expect TA in view of the other scribblings in TA, and the faint first note might be in TA, but the second, larger scribbling seems to be in TB.

– (p)räl: It is suggestive to think of (mā p)räl '[This book] is (not) to be taken [away from the monastery].'

In the last section in this line, the oblique case of caṣ postäk requires another construction than the standard säs postäk mā präl 'this book is not to be taken'. If mar is read correctly, the corresponding subjunctive could simply have to be restored, i.e. 2Sg.Sub.Mid. mar (kāmatār) 'you may not take; don't take!' or 3Sg.Sub.Mid. mar (kāmatär) 'he may not take'.

b5 The unskilled akṣaras to the left of mokṣakute ṣāmner appear to make no sense; the akṣaras to the right of it so far allow for no interpretation.

• How to transliterate/-scribe such cases, where colophons/glosses in TA and/or TB are scribbled/added at the end of a text, partially overlapping?

"The Sanskrit Udānavarga and the Tocharian B Udānastotra: a window on the relationship between religious and popular language on the northern Silk Road". It's <bibl><title corresp="ref:peyrot2016a"/></bibl>, but the pages need to be added. –Martin (Thu, 2018-07-26, 19:24:27 (CEST))</li></ul> </li><li>I changed the expedition code from "T III <b>So</b> 64, 90, 101" (which was copied from IDP) to "T III <b>Š</b> 64" etc. (which is written on both, the fragments and the frame). I also added the images and the link to IDP. –Martin (Thu, 2018-07-26, 19:29:45 (CEST))</li><li>The different parts of the text, now irregularly separated by "...", have yet to be marked correctly. –Martin (Tue, 2018-10-09, 14:28:57 (CEST))</li></ul></project_comment>
